title.narrative: We are able! DR Congo

description.narrative: By 2025, through engagement with public authorities (formal and informal powerholders), men, women and youth with disabilities and other excluded groups, through resilient and capable local CSOs/DPOs in this fragile and conflict-affected country, are successfully influencing laws, policies, practices and norms for improved food security for all.

The We are able! program targets people (including women, men, and youth) with a disability, while, as spin-off, the program will also create opportunities for other excluded groups,3 such as vulnerable women, persons affected by leprosy, youth in general, excluded ethnic groups, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, as much as possible or necessary in the specific context. Intersectional traits often make people particularly vulnerable. Refugees with disabilities or disabled women and men of particular ethnic backgrounds often face the most severe forms of food insecurity. We are able! identifies and targets groups and individuals with particular vulnerabilities while creating synergies that allow others to benefit as well.

The activities in DR Congo are part of the We are able! program in DR Congo, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. Food security in these countries is low. People with disabilities (PWDs) are even more likely to live in food insecure households. We are able! wants to see PWDs improving their right to food and food security by creating an enabling environment for right-to-food action at grassroots level. While PWDs are the core target group of the We are able! program, we create benefits for other excluded groups like vulnerable women, youth in general, marginalised ethnic groups and internally displaced persons (IDPs), as applicable per context.

title.narrative: SCS3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage Methodological notes
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) AHADI: The organisation has lobbied at the level of the local authorities (chiefdom, administrator) to grant them a plot of land where they can establish their association. This has been granted. They have conducted training in groups of persons with and without disabilities to increase respect and social inclusion. 2) AHID: Lobby for the release of illegally arrested persons with disabilities. The organisation pleaded with all relevant administrations and authorities and have started seeing results. 3) AHID: The organisation has created visibility of persons with disabilities through various activities including regular appearances on local radio. Through their beekeeping project the organisation is known for its high quality honey produced by its members. This has led to recognition and respect resulting in local authorities participating in the yearly international day of the person living with a disability and the willingness of local authorities to assist persons with disabilities whenever needed. 4) AHID: The organisation has managed to ensure that its members are invited to participate in meetings at the chiefdom level. Participation in these meetings creates space to influence discussions. 5) FEUPAS Grand Lac: The organisation, in collaboration with local authorities, created fishponds to open up opportunities for persons with disabilities to generate income to increase their independence. The ponds have been established with the permission of Provincial and local authorities. 6) AGSAMH Advocacy for the participation of persons with disabilities in security councils. It was established that from now on, a representative of persons with disabilities participates and speaks on behalf of persons with disabilities in the decision-making bodies. Before when authorities met they did not take into account the needs and interests of persons with disabilities but now persons with disabilities are represented. 7) FOJEVI Bushovu Advocacy for the representation of persons with disabilities in local meetings. Persons with disabilities now receive invitations or have access to the announcements in order to represent themselves in the various decision-making bodies. 8) APVH Facilitate access to agricultural inputs for person with disabilities. The organisation identified all persons in need of agricultural inputs and shared the list with the president of the CPR (Cooperative?). Inputs were distributed to all the identified persons on the list.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: 1) Mungumwa Buholo: The organisation has promoted the employment of persons with disabilities within the public and private sector. The organisation had identified persons with disabilities within the community capable of working and wrote letters to all partners 7 and influential stakeholders. As a consequence the chiefdom's civil registrar is a person with a disability and the secretary of the group's office is also a person with a disability. 2) AVMC: The organisation lobbied for a change in mentality with regards to the treatment of persons with Albinism. Sacrificing and ritual murders of persons with Albinism still occurs in Congo. To decrease this practice the organisation brought together relevant actors in charge of security issues such as the Congolese National Police, the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the National Intelligence Agency, the chiefdom, local leaders and human rights organisations. The organisation had documented all the cases of insecurity and death threats against albinos in different villages. The organisation advocated for the abandonment of these bad practices and educated families of persons with albinism and persons with albinism to be vigilant, not to be alone in isolated places and not to walk around in the late hours.

title.narrative: SCS2 # of laws, policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement.
# of governmental policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: AGSAMH In collaboration with other organisations, AGSAMH has been able to block a policy imposing taxes on persons living with disabilities carrying out commercial activities at the chiefdom level. AGSAMH in collaboration with other organisations have managed to obtain tax exemptions for persons with disabilities running small-scale businesses. They have also managed to have authorities give out ‘indulgence cards’ to persons with disabilities with small-scale businesses at the Territory level. This card helps prevent harassment by persons demanding tax. Before these cards were given out, persons with disabilities were regularly harassed, sometimes illegally arrested and their goods stolen. According to the organisation the harassment has seized. FOJEVI Bushovo In collaboration with other organisations, FOJEVI has been able to block a policy imposing taxes on people living with disabilities carrying out commercial activities at the chiefdom level. (See information under AGSAMH for more details). AVMC In collaboration with other organisations, AVMC has been able to block a policy imposing taxes on people living with disabilities (PVH) carrying out commercial activities at the chiefdom level. (See information under AGSAMH for more details).

title.narrative: # of laws blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: AGSAMH The organisation succeeded in enforcing compliance with the rights of parents of a baby with disabilities to register their baby at the Chieftaincy Civil Status Office. Before the organisation noted that persons with disabilities could not present their birth certificate and many even did not know about the existence of such certificates. The organisation raised awareness of the general public on the rights to register a baby with disabilities and at the level of the Civil Status Office to comply with the birth registration law. The other achievement of the organisation was making the birth certificates free of charge. Before a fee was charged for these birth certificates. This could also be counted under SCS011, but the WeAreAble consortium does not report under this indicator.

title.narrative: SCS4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
# of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) AHID: Awareness raising on the rights of people living with disabilities and the inclusion in decision-making through the OBUGUMA community radio station. 2) AGSAMH: Before, in the event of childbirth of a baby with disabilities, the mother ran the risk of being abandoned by her husband, many have complained to us about this. This is why we have sensitized men in churches so that they come to understand having a disabled child it is not the fault of the child let alone that of his mother, it is the will of God. 3) AGSAMH: Raising awareness about the interests and needs of persons with disabilities. Mobilization in churches showing that persons with disabilities are capable of many things and that among them there are some who are very intelligent. They have created sub-groups in each village. 4) FOJEVI: Advocacy against discrimination of persons with disabilities in schools. 5) FEUPAS Grand Lac: Advocacy for the education of persons with hearing impairments 6) APVH: Advocacy about the rights and needs of persons with disabilities and their families. 7) AVMC: The organisation pleaded for free passage through barriers (erected to collect taxes) in the chiefdom. 8) AVMC: AVMC lobbied for the equal access to jobs for persons with disabilities. 9) AVMC: ) Advocacy for the special needs of persons with disabilities during conflict and war. 10) AVMC: AVMC works in synergy with other actors. The objective is to bring together the efforts and know-how of all actors. 11) Mungumwa Buholo: Mungumwa Buholo works in a network (including AVMC) to collectively advocate for the interest and needs of persons with disabilities and persons with albinism. 12) Mungumwa Buholo: Sensitization, mobilization and mass education of the community with the support of local leaders and other actors in the community so that the security and safety of persons with disabilities, elderly people and albinos is taken into account. 13) UHSD: UHSD had persuaded other local organisations and associations to advocate together in favour of people living with disabilities. They jointly addressed the issue of taking into account the needs and interests of persons with disabilities and ways to integrate them. 14) UHSD Raising awareness of the community on the inclusion of persons with disabilities through radio messages. 15) ADTPA: To educate the community and local authorities and increase awareness about the rights and needs of persons with disabilities they use community radio. 16) APROMOTCO: Advocate for the construction of an training centre for learning trades such as sewing to support those members who have suffered serious accidents which have made them unable to drive a taxi motorcycle. 17) UOEBU: Promote the rights of persons with disabilities to have equal access to Village Savings and Credit Associations (VSCAs) by demanding the New Civil Society for their support in making member associations aware of the need to comply with the rights of persons with disabilities to join the (VSCAs).

title.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

comment.narrative: No cases of advocacy initiatives with membership/constituency found.
